race.name: Hart Hills
race.tagline: Hart Hills. 55 miles of gravel through Hart.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Michigan countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Michigan event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Hart Hills is a local event in Michigan—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Michigan countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Michigan gravel race. Worth it for Michigan/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Michigan—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Michigan races: Barry-Roubaix, Iceman Cometh.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Hart has limited lodging options. Book ahead.
logistics.food: Hart has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Michigan rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Downtown Hart start/finish keeps things simple, and Friday night packet pickup behind Hart Pizza has small-town accessibility. Race director Raymond Passchier delivers pre-race announcements with specific course warnings like "sand at mile 23" and "large pothole at mile 32 - stay left." The 9 AM start gives you time for coffee and regret.

length.explanation: The 55-mile distance earned respect from elite rider Christina Vipond: "Three hours and 39 minutes of hills, wind and sand! Hart Hills was the most challenging course I have raced yet." Tracy Gravlin, who chose the 26-mile option, admitted "I am happy I signed up for the 26 mile race and not the 55. Phew." It's neither century epic nor quick hit.

technicality.explanation: The course features multiple deep sand sections that force riders to dismount. Tracy Gravlin described "a 2 track that was very deep sand and no way to get off to the side to ride" followed by "a steep downhill in beach sand." She witnessed "some wiped out" while she chose to run her bike through the sand sections.

elevation.explanation: The 55-mile course packs 3,000 feet of climbing according to rider reports, slightly more than the listed 2,500 feet. Christina Vipond noted the profile-busting reality: "I rounded a corner on the seasonal road and, of course there it was [the long steep climb], not on a gravel road." The climbing is relentless but not altitude-threatening.

climate.explanation: May weather proved variable but manageable across race years. The 2025 edition started at 55°F and foggy before "the sun came out during the race" and became "just the right temp." Wind dominates the challenge - Christina Vipond experienced gusts so strong that "one more gust of wind made me stop riding completely because it was pushing me into the lane of an oncoming truck."

altitude.explanation: Hart sits at basically sea level in western Michigan, maybe 600 feet above actual sea level. Your biggest altitude concern is whether your ears pop on the plane ride home. This is Great Lakes flat, not even Appalachian foothills flat.

adventure.explanation: The course routes through "asparagus fields and orchards" with unexpected challenges at named segments. The sharp "Remember" turn surprises riders with "a downhill turn onto a washed out, sandy two-track" - unexpected enough that riders laugh and say "seriously?" to volunteers. Course includes seasonal roads that can be completely washed out.

prestige.explanation: Hart Hills is a regional Michigan series race with zero national recognition and no notable pro field. No prize purse, no media coverage, just age group medals for the locals. It's part of the Michigan Gravel Race Series, which tells you exactly how far your bragging rights travel.

race_quality.explanation: They've got chip timing from Epic Race Timing and named segments like Hart Breaker Hill, so someone's paying attention to details. The race claims to be 'probably one of the toughest gravel races in lower Michigan,' but that's like being the tallest building in Topeka. Post-race pizza and beer suggests they understand the basics of not making people hate them.

experience.explanation: You get segments with names like 'Remember Kelly' and 'Stan's Stomping Grounds' - local flavor that means something to exactly nobody outside Hart, Michigan. The race starts and ends downtown at 105 E Main St, so you'll see all of Hart's bustling metropolis. Four distance options from 13 to 55 miles means they're trying to please everyone, which usually pleases no one completely.

community.explanation: Friday night packet pickup behind Hart Pizza creates small-town accessibility, and volunteers bring humor to challenging sections. Tracy Gravlin credited her gravel skills training: "I am happy with my riding in the sand and putting to use what i have learned in BaseCamp." Post-race brews and pizza at the finish line maintain cycling culture basics.

field_depth.explanation: This is pure regional racing with no data on field size or competitive depth. No mention of any notable winners or pro participation because there aren't any. You're racing against weekend warriors from Grand Rapids and whoever drove up from Kalamazoo.

value.explanation: Four distance options from 13 to 55 miles, chip timing, pre-race briefings with course warnings, volunteer support at technical sections, and post-race food and drinks provide solid race-day value. The course delivers on its "toughest gravel race in lower Michigan" promise without breaking the bank in rural Hart.

expenses.explanation: Hart isn't a tourist destination, so lodging and food costs stay reasonable without Traverse City resort pricing. Equipment choices matter more than travel costs - Tracy Gravlin immediately regretted bringing 40c tires instead of 50c Gravel Kings after pre-riding the sandy course. Gas money remains your biggest expense unless you're local to West Michigan.
